title: Integration Studio—Datadog integration
content:
Overview

It is now possible to integrate with Datadog by using the Integration Studio. The Datadog integration templates support the following use cases:

  • Datadog Incident to SMAX Incident
  • Schedule downtime in Datadog
Note: The integration use cases described in this document serve as examples to inspire and guide your integration efforts. However, they should not be considered as prescriptive or guaranteed solutions for your particular scenario. The examples may or may not be applicable to your license edition.

Use case—Datadog Incident to SMAX Incident exchange

This is a typical case exchange use case, where an Event in Datadog first becomes an Incident in Datadog, which is then forwarded to SMAX to create an Incident in Service Management.

The use case in a nutshell is illustrated below:

Use case—Schedule downtime

This use case enables you to schedule downtime in Datadog. In case a change request in Service Management has scheduled downtime planned for the involved CIs, the downtime data can be forwarded to Datadog. Datadog will then not raise events for the involved CIs during the scheduled downtime.

Technical overview

The following diagram illustrates the involved components for the provided example use cases.

Incident exchange:

  1. An Incident is created in Datadog out of one or more Datadog events. 
  2. For every Incident create or update action, a webhook is triggered in Datadog.
  3. The webhook in Datadog pushes the data to the listener in the SMAX Integration Studio.
  4. The Datadog scenario associated with the listener is triggered.
  5. The scenario creates or updates the Incident in Service Management.
  6. Certain updates of the Incident in Service Management trigger another integration scenario to prepare the data for Datadog.
  7. The system updates the Incident in Datadog.

Schedule downtime:

  1. A change request is set up in Service Management with a scheduled downtime. This will trigger the integration scenario for creating downtimes in Datadog for each CI attached to the change.
  2. The integration scenario will forward the downtime details for every CI to Datadog.
  3. The integration scenario will update the change request with details about the status of the downtime creation.

Set up the integration

The procedure below will set up the integration with Datadog to achieve the documented example use cases.

Generate API and application keys in Datadog

To integrate with Datadog, you need an API key and an application key during the SMAX integration endpoint configuration.

To get an API key, follow the steps in the Datadog documentation: API and Application Keys.

For the application key, we recommend creating a Service Account with the required scopes (permissions). Then create an application key from the newly created Service Account.

Prepare an integration user

Perform the following steps to prepare an integration user:

  1. Create an integration user. See How to create an integration user.

  2. Log in to the Agent Portal of SMAX as the tenant admin, navigate to Administration > Master Data > People, locate the integration user, and then assign the proper roles to perform the required actions like creating or updating incidents. The user must also have a role with the On-Premise Bridge/Integration Administrator permission.  Alternatively, assign the Tenant Admin role to grant general access.

  3. (If not Tenant Admin) Navigate to Administration > Master Data > People > Roles, and create a new role with Create, View, and Update permissions for the External reference and External system record types.

Create an endpoint

Create an endpoint using the Rest Executor 2.0 endpoint type:

  1. Log in to the agent interface as the tenant admin.
  2. Navigate to Administration > Utilities > Integration > Endpoints.
  3. Click Add.
  4. Select Rest Executor 2.0 as the endpoint type, enter a name for the endpoint (for example, Datadog), and then click Add. The system creates the endpoint.
  5. Click Configure and complete the required fields.
Field Value
General configuration
Agent Select Agentless for a direct connection to the Datadog API.
Authentication type Select No Auth
Protocol Select https.
Base URL Enter the base URL of the Datadog API: https://api.<datadog site>
Certificate type Optional
Certificate format Optional
Server certificate Optional
Configure headers

Header 1

 Key: DD-API-KEY
HTTP element: Header
Value: <The Datadog API key>

Header 2

 Key: DD-APPLICATION-KEY
Http element: Header
Value: <The Datadog application key>

Create an integration

Create an integration and configure one or more scenarios to define the business logic for the Incident exchange or Downtime synchronization between SMAX and Datadog.

The Datadog connector has three predefined scenario templates: 

  • Process webhooks for Incidents, to receive and handle notifications from Datadog
  • Update Incident in Datadog, to send SMAX incident updates to Datadog
  • Schedule downtime, to schedule downtimes for CIs in Datadog

In the following steps, you'll create an integration with the predefined templates.

  1. Navigate to Administration > Utilities > Integration > Integration Studio. 
  2. Click New and enter the name of the integration.
  3. Configure the integration user that you created above for the local SMAX system.
  4. In the Connector-Endpoint mappings section, click Add, select Datadog as the connector and select the Datadog endpoint, and then enter an alias for the mapping.
  5. Activate the integration.
  6. Click Save.

Add and configure the scenarios

Perform the following steps to add the scenarios to the Datadog integration:

  1. Click Add scenario. 
  2. Enter a name for the scenario. For example, Process webhooks for Incidents.
  3. In the Template field, select Process webhooks for Incidents from the list. 
  4. Click Save to add the scenario.
  5. Repeat the steps above to add two more scenarios based on the other scenario templates.
Note: Using templates will make the integration configuration easier than starting from scratch. If you don't select this option, you'll have to manually add your own logic, starting from a blank page. 

The following table describes the parameters that you can modify to control the behavior of the scenarios. These parameters are located in the Settings rule at the start of the Process logic section. Modify them before you run the scenarios.

Scenario name Options to be considered before using the scenario 

Process webhooks for Incidents

In the Listener section of the scenario, add a listener of type URL token. This listener URL is then used to send Datadog notifications to Service Management.


 
In the Default settings rule at the start of the process logic, you can configure settings to influence the behavior of the scenario. At a minimum, you need to enter data for the following parameters:

  • Service – The name of the Service against which the Incident is created.
  • Group – The UPN of the group to assign the Incident.
  • Category – The name of the category to set for the Incident.

The other parameters are optional. They can be used to set the default data when the Incident is created.

  • Description – The default description in case no description is sent by Datadog.
  • Title – The default title in case no title is sent by Datadog.
  • Impact – The default impact of the Incident.
  • Urgency – The default urgency in case no Severity is sent by Datadog.
  • RemoteSystem – The remote system name required by the case exchange API.
  • ExternalEntityType – The Datadog entity type.
  • SMAXDrillDownURL – The URL to access the SMAX Incident.

Update Incident in Datadog 

 In the Settings rule at the start of the process logic, you can configure settings to influence the behavior of the scenario. The following parameters are optional:
  • RemoteSystem – The remote system name required by the case exchange API. Must be the same value as that of the same parameter in the “Process webhooks for Incidents” scenario.
  • ExternalEntityType – The Datadog entity type. Must be the same value as that of the same parameter in the “Process webhooks for Incidents” scenario.
Schedule downtime In the Settings rule at the start of the process logic, you can configure settings to influence the behavior of the scenario. The following parameters are required:
  • MonitorId – The ID of the Datadog monitor for which to schedule the downtime.

Configure Datadog

Create a webhook

  1. Go to Integrations > Integrations.

  2. Search for webhooks. If not already done, install the webhooks capability.

  3. Create a new webhook within the webhooks capability.
  4. Enter a name. For example: Service Management.
  5. Copy the Listener URL from the Process webhooks for Incidents scenario to the URL field.
  6. Copy the following code to the Payload field: 
    {
   "id": "$INCIDENT_PUBLIC_ID",
   "url": "$INCIDENT_URL" 
}

  7. Click Save.

Modify Incident settings

  1. Go to Service Mgmt > Incidents > Settings.

  2. Click Property Fields in the left pane.

  3. Do the following in the What Happened section:

    1. Update the Summary field as follows:

      • Prompted: At Declaration

Create Incident forwarding rules

Configure a rule to trigger the webhook to forward Incidents to Service Management.

  1. Go to Service Mgmt > Incidents > Settings.

  2. Click Rules under Notifications in the left pane.

  3. Add a new rule. Make sure to select the webhook you created for the SMAX integration in the Notify field.

Example:

Note: This is just one example on how to trigger notifications to Service Management. For additional options, check the Datadog documentation.

Use the scenarios

This section describes the additional steps required to use the scenarios.

Process webhooks for Incidents

Note: This scenario is designed to work with the SMAX Incident record type.

To use this scenario, perform the Datadog configurations as documented above and set the required parameters in the Default settings rule of the scenario in Integration Studio.

Then declare an Incident in Datadog and observe the notification arrive in the Datadog endpoint in Service Management. Once all rules are successfully finished, check the created Incident.

Update Incident in Datadog

Note: This scenario is designed to work with the SMAX Incident record type.

This scenario will send updates from the SMAX Incident to the Datadog Incident. Comments added to the SMAX incident are added to the summary field in Datadog. The incident resolution is added to the root cause field in Datadog.

To trigger the updates to be sent to Datadog, a business rule of type “Call Integration Engine” needs to be added to the Service Management Studio for the Incident record type in the After applying changes section.

The rule should have the following condition:
${(current_update.Comments.IsChanged || entity.Solution!=null) && current_user.Upn != '<UPN of the Integration user>' && lookup('ExternalReference','RemoteSystem','EntityType','Incident','EntityId',entity.Id,'RemoteSystem','Datadog')=='Datadog'}

  • Enter the UPN of the integration user used by the Integration Studio Datadog integration.
  • If you changed the default value of the RemoteSystem parameter in the Settings rule in the scenarios, change Datadog above to that value.

Schedule downtime

Note: This scenario is designed to work with the SMAX Change record type.

One option to schedule a downtime is to create a custom action that triggers the Integration Studio scenario to forward downtimes to Datadog.

  1. Go to Studio and select the Change record type.
  2. Open the Custom actions tab and add a new custom action. Ensure you select the Enable workflow checkbox.
    Example:
  3. Open the Processes and Rules tab to add the business rule in the After applying changes section to trigger the Integration Studio scenario when the custom action is clicked.
    The rule should have the following condition:
    ${entity.CustomActionName_c=='Downtimes' && current_update.CustomActionCount_c.IsChanged}
